1124854312138448897.text: Well, that's a first: I ordered a $1,000 item from @Amazon available in Prime, and received a $90 fake instead. I'm sending it back and I'm sure they will issue a refund, but I can't find a proper way to report fakes as a buyer.

1118930195317051392.text: I'd strongly encourage folks to read the real thing. The legal decisions and the surrounding political commentary are not going to change anyone's mind, but the now largely public operational details should be very interesting to the folks in our industry.

1118929383736037376.text: Not here for the politics (yeah right), but the first 50 pages of the Mueller report contain a really nice treasure trove of details about the compromise, data exfil, and comms tactics of a state-sponsored adversary.

1099369442675314689.text: Solving it requires finesse that regulators usually lack. But you know: I am fairly tranquil about my "cyber" risk. I am far more unsettled about the privacy practices in the industry - in part because they remain shielded from view and have not been properly "priced in". (5/5)

1099369442025197574.text: Where we fail as an industry is helping people with unique security or privacy needs. If some facet of your online presence is more valuable than the "society average", we don't have an end-to-end solution for you - and not many companies are seriously investing in that. (4/5)

1099369441345716224.text: To abuse an analogy: when most of us don't mind that our front locks can be picked with a bent paperclip, yet we call for government action after every breach, I can't help but think that we sound a bit like the overeager door lock salesmen of infosec. (3/5)

1099369440708255744.text: In that sense, I suspect the market has actually arrived at a pretty good infosec equilibrium that balances tech progress with social costs. Sure, this equilibrium rubs many pros the wrong way - but that's hardly an argument for intervention. (2/5)

1099369439928020992.text: I think that's a pessimistic view. Over the past two decades, we've gotten dramatically better with most aspects of infosec. Sure, high-profile breaches happen - but despite alarmism, their lasting impact on most people is not merely "externalized"; it's pretty nil. (1/5)https://twitter.com/NielsProvos/status/1099136820539940864 …

1091177373695803393.text: I mean, they weren't exactly subtlepic.twitter.com/ZYMXC2l8ya

1088936934863384576.text: And a video of the talk: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9xePC0Tyeuc#t=1h15m50s …https://twitter.com/lcamtuf/status/1083056717171019777 …

1083056717171019777.text: Did we mention that we had end-to-end encryption of 1-1 Snaps for quite some time now? If you're at Real World Crypto in San Jose today, be sure to check out the 10:05 talk by Subhash Sankuratripati!

1078738819120123904.text: Ultimately, I believe that the moral compass must come mostly from within. If you are not explicitly trying to be radically different in how you approach privacy, security, and content policing on your platform, you are destined to end up the same as everybody else. (9/9)

1078738818361057280.text: A natural instinct for many of us is to demand regulatory solutions - but in my experience, regulatory involvement in this area severely lacks thoughtfulness and long-term insight. It is also often exacerbated by poorly-researched or misleading journalistic exposes. (8/9)

1078738817379557377.text: With intense political pressure, not doing it is not an option. But doing it well is an impossibility - not at the scale they operate, not without collateral damage, not without their own politics tainting the outcome. Or, as @alexstamos puts it: https://twitter.com/alexstamos/status/1078677650414006272 … (7/9)

1078738816624558080.text: The final problem is inherent to building platforms that serve as a conduit for communications and commerce on an unprecedented scale. Willing or not, this makes the companies the arbiters of all human conduct, from acceptable political speech to the sale of fireworks. (6/9)

1078738815609581569.text: They are ultimately building a world that doesn't forget and doesn't forgive - and where dirt can be dug up on any opponent - by a government, by a hacker, by a spouse. On a very human level, this page still creeps me out: https://myaccount.google.com/purchases  (5/9)

1078738814753943552.text: The other vice I see is the inherent hazard of tying your long-term strategy to knowing everything there is to know about your users' lives. The companies do it for good if self-serving reasons - and of all possible actors in that role, I trust them the most. But... (4/9)

1078738814007312384.text: In essence: if you don't write a set of immutable principles ahead of the time, if you don't draw some clear lines in the sand - you will wake up one day in a very different business and not know why. (3/9)

1078738813256531969.text: At the same time, they succumb to three vices. The first is incrementalism: every month, there is an intense competitive pressure to make small compromises on how you approach security and privacy; such individually unimportant tweaks add up to profound shifts over time. (2/9)

1078738812543455232.text: Thread: there are countless urban legends and misconceptions about the practices of tech companies such as Google and Facebook. In my experience, they take extremely good care of your data; they guard it with zeal that's unmatched by most other players in the industry. (1/9)

1048359333824614400.text: One of the best rules to live by is: be especially suspicious of claims that align with your views, for they dull your critical facilities. And seek out the best arguments of the other side, rather than ridiculing their worst.

1047874245944963073.text: There is probably a component of truth to the Bloomberg story, and probably some legit intelligence findings underpinning it, but I have serious doubts that the reporting is substantially accurate.

1047873928838836225.text: Of particular note: the unambiguous denials from the security teams of the companies named in the article, the unclear access path,, the seemingly unnecessary burning of a very sophisticated tool on a seemingly non-targeted attack against a boring platform.

1047872914316439552.text: Right. I have no special knowledge here, but given the exceptional claims made by Bloomberg and having seen several other cases of spectacularly inaccurate reporting cast in a very similar mold, I'd advise a lot of caution. Still prudent to worry about hw supply chains.

952267239595507713.text: Plus, of course, we stopped worrying after the end of the Cold War. And that's probably fine, because the risk of a nuclear confrontation is a lot lower than it was back then. Cuban Missile Crisis is hard to top.

952266794940620801.text: Oh: the reason why you don't know that is because nuclear disarmament activists had vested interest in exaggerating the already-awful effects of nuclear attacks and instilling a sense of hopelessness to advance (noble) goals. Mocking duck-and-cover was a part of that.

952266142533300224.text: By far the most significant risk is the shockwave and the thermal radiation from the burst, and shelter - any shelter - can keep you alive. Now back to playing Fallout...

952265873145831424.text: In short, ducking and taking cover is actually a pretty good strategy, fallout from air bursts is relatively modest and decays very quickly to reasonably safe levels (days to weeks, versus centuries), clean water and food can be sourced in the aftermath.

952265416289632256.text: For folks who are interested in the real consequences of a nuclear attack and the odds of survival, this is a surprisingly good science-based book from the 1960s that cuts through most of the Hollywood-perpetuated myths: http://www.madisoncountyema.com/nwss.pdf

946275314228871169.text: I applaud many of the bold infosec visionaries on Twitter who are predicting that breaches are going to continue and perhaps even grow in 2018.

943653278981558273.text: Believe it or not, but back in the 90s, we had to fiddle with all kinds of different connectors to hook up peripherals to our machines... PS/2, Centronics, RS232C, oh my! Of course today, thanks to the wonders of standardization, it's a thing of the past.pic.twitter.com/LUapF26p0z

939668596430475264.text: For what it's worth... having interviewed 300+ people over the past ~20 years, I feel that past modest threshold, industry visibility correlates negatively with skill demonstrated in job interviews. Ownership of OSS projects feels like a far more reliable predictor of talent.

938801886211194880.text: You knew about BTC in 2010, 2012, 2015. You probably didn't buy because you couldn't convincingly reason about its value. If the only new variable today is intense remorse and a desire not to miss out, you're not gonna make a smart decision - at best, a lucky one.

935408343929184256.text: That can be a lot more about clever UX and API design, seamless resource provisioning, integration with bug trackers and continuous build systems, and powerful test case minimization and diagnostics tools.

935405892937310213.text: One of the most important OSS security efforts of this decade is the one you have not heard about: https://github.com/google/oss-fuzz/ …. Check out the trophy list.
